prompt: Facts: Incident occurred on October 29, 1992, around 7:30 PM in the fields near Village Nangal Sirohi, District Mahendergarh, Haryana.; Parties involved: Accused side - Bhagirath, Jagdish (appellants, sons), Hukmi (father); Complainant/Deceased side - Jeet Singh (deceased), Chhotu Ram (deceased), Balbir Singh (PW4, eyewitness), Rattan Singh.; Prosecution version (per PW4 Balbir Singh): Accused were found cutting Bajra crop from a field claimed by Balbir Singh's father. When the complainant party objected, Hukmi exhorted his sons to attack. Bhagirath attacked Jeet Singh with a 'jailly' (spear/pitchfork), and Jagdish attacked Chhotu Ram with a 'jailly'. Hukmi allegedly wielded a lathi. Jeet Singh and Chhotu Ram died due to injuries.; Defense version (Accused statements under S.313 CrPC, DW1 testimony): The field belonged to the accused (supported by revenue records). The complainant party were the aggressors, armed with weapons ('kassi', 'jailly'), attempting to forcibly take possession or harvest the crop. Chhotu Ram allegedly hit Hukmi with a 'kassi', and Jeet Singh hit Bhagirath with a 'jailly'. Bhagirath claimed he snatched the 'jailly' from Jeet Singh and struck back in self-defense. Jagdish claimed he hit Chhotu Ram in self-defense.; Medical Evidence: Jeet Singh had three incised wounds, including a fatal penetrating wound in the chest. Chhotu Ram had one fatal penetrating wound in the chest. Accused Hukmi had a lacerated wound, abrasions, and contusion. Accused Bhagirath had an abrasion.; Trial Court: Convicted Bhagirath and Jagdish under Section 302 read with Section 34 IPC (life imprisonment). Acquitted Hukmi. Rejected the plea of private defense.; High Court: Upheld the Trial Court's conviction and sentence.; Supreme Court: Appeal filed by Bhagirath and Jagdish against the High Court's judgment. | IPC: Section 34 (Common Intention), Section 96 (Right of Private Defence - Act done in private defence), Section 97 (Right of private defence of the body and of property), Section 99 (Acts against which there is no right of private defence; Extent to which the right may be exercised), Section 100 (When the right of private defence of the body extends to causing death), Section 103 (When the right of private defence of property extends to causing death), Section 300 (Murder), Section 300 Exception 2 (Culpable homicide is not murder if offender exceeds right of private defence in good faith), Section 302 (Punishment for Murder), Section 304 Part I (Punishment for culpable homicide not amounting to murder - with intention), Section 304 Part II (Punishment for culpable homicide not amounting to murder - with knowledge)
completion: {"prosecution": [{"argument": "The accused were aggressors committing theft/mischief on land belonging to the complainant party. When confronted, they formed a common intention, exhorted by Hukmi, and intentionally murdered Jeet Singh and Chhotu Ram.", "precedents": ["Virsa Singh v. State of Punjab (AIR 1958 SC 465)", "Suresh v. State of U.P. ((2001) 3 SCC 673)", "Patil Hari Meghji v. State of Gujarat ((1983) 2 SCC 270)"]}], "defense": [{"argument": "The accused were lawfully present on their own land when the complainant party, armed and acting as aggressors, attacked them. The accused acted in good faith exercise of their right of private defense of person and property (Sections 96, 97, 100, 103 IPC).", "precedents": ["Munshi Ram v. Delhi Administration (AIR 1968 SC 702)", "Deo Narain v. State of U.P. (AIR 1973 SC 473)", "Yogendra Morarji v. State of Gujarat (AIR 1980 SC 660)"]}, {"argument": "Alternatively, even if the force used exceeded the strict bounds of private defense, it was done without premeditation and without intention to cause more harm than necessary for defense, falling under Exception 2 to Section 300 IPC. The offense would be culpable homicide not amounting to murder (Section 304 IPC).", "precedents": ["James Martin v. State of Kerala ((2004) 2 SCC 203)", "Bhanwar Singh v. State of Madhya Pradesh ((2008) 16 SCC 657)", "Surain Singh v. State of Punjab ((2017) 5 SCC 796)"]}, {"argument": "The injuries sustained by Hukmi and Bhagirath corroborate the defense version that the complainant party initiated the violence.", "precedents": ["Lakshmi Singh v. State of Bihar ((1976) 4 SCC 394)", "State of Rajasthan v. Madho (AIR 1991 SC 1065)", "Ram Sunder Yadav v. State of Bihar ((1998) 7 SCC 365)"]}]}
